I expected this to be a stereotypical love drama and I was not incorrect in that assumption. However, as the slow, repetitive episodes lingered and the characters followed suit; I realized that the characters themselves began to mean more and more. Usually character development and change is the inciting factor for the overall and continued endearment of a character, but in Suzuka, the impervious resolution of the characters to stick to who they are, is actually their most charming characteristic. 
If you are into love/drama/comedy (there seems to be intended and even more unintended comedy throughout), and you can stick around through the rough andfrustratingly stubborn characters; you may eventually see that sometimes what someone is made out of is polished through repetition, and that foolhardy, passion does mean something. There are easier ways to do things but Yamato Akitsuki and Suzuka do not understand the easy route. Sometimes, 'there is no right and wrong in love, and a person is neither wrong nor right.' If legitimate and sincere love is there, it is very difficult to replace or cover it up.

With Suzuka you will either love/like it or hate it.  The show starts rather unimpressive in the beginning episodes but begins to find its stride around the 5th and 6th episodes.    
At first I really didn't think much of Suzuka but by the end I knew it had an some kind of impact on me.  Suzuka's magic comes from how people builds walls around themselves that prevent them moving on with their lives and it's this message that the show conveys in a way that doesn't totally browbeat you over the head with it.
The story is your basic boy meetsgirl.   Yamato a boy from the country moves to a new city to find a new life and there he meets a beautiful track star named Suzuka.  Little does he know the girl he likes lives right next door to him.  Yamato and Suzuka quickly develop a friendship and start to develop feelings for one another kept in the safe land of vagueness of friendship, then Yamato confesses to Suzuka at the park and he gets rejected and it's after this rejection the real story begins.  Little does Yamato know why Suzuka rejected him even though she had sadness and regret in her eyes when she did.  The whole story revolves around Suzuka why she is the way she is.  Now I don't want to spoil it but there is a lesson in the last episode that saying anything more would give away too much.


Suzuka tends to get a lot of hate because many people who watch it have no idea the characterizations of the two main characters are based on reality.  In reality there are people like Suzuka and Yamato and even worse.  So whether or not you can relate to the main characters depends highly on your own maturity level and awareness of the kinds of people in the real world around you.


That being said there are some problems with the characterization however where the characters do some things that don't make sense.  Particularly with Suzuka and her past and the way she seems unrealistically fickle towards the end of the series with Yamato which tends to drag out the conflict between them.   Yamato on the other hand tends to be the most realistically rendered character - he begins as your typical indecisive teenager but starts getting serious about having goals in his own life and grows as a character.


The pacing of the story can be problematic.  The show tries to juggle too many things.   Between doing sports, the conflict between Suzuka and Yamato, and how the anime flirts with side relationships with the other girls besides Suzuka.  There were simply not enough episodes to make sure other side characters got enough screen time to be characterized correctly.   In short, the anime directors couldn't figure out what they wanted to focus on so Suzuka tends to drag out its conflict between the two main characters.


But if you can get over the fact this anime drags something out a little too long and don't mind your anime with some flaws and you dig a more realistic take on romance then Suzuka is right up your alley.

First of all, Akitsuki is a little BITCH!
That is mainly what this review is about, and it is to warn you that if you don't wanna follow a shitty male lead for 26 episodes, then don't bother with this show. If this doesn't bother you too much, Suzuka is definitely worth checking out.
Suzuka is a fine romance anime but it would b A LOT better if it didn't have one of the worst male leads ever. Seriously, if we are going to spend 80% of the show following Akitsuki Yamato's actions and thoughts, then it sure as hell would be a whole lot more enjoyableif Akitsuki wasn't a total bitch. Beyond Akitsuki Yamato literally being a whiny crybaby, the rest of the show was good, altho the enjoyment factor does go down bcuz no1 can enjoy a show if the lead is a pussy.\n\n

8/10, give it a try, its still worth the time.

Suzuka is an anime that initially shows great potential but then slowly ambles its way across the finish line. The drama in this show comes from the troubled romance between the main characters and the complications that they mostly create for themselves. In some cases this can be funny and interesting, particularly when the characters are likable and you want to see them succeed. However, in the case of Suzuka, both of the main leads are highly unlikable people and you sort of want to see them jump off a tall building - preferably together.
The supporting cast isn't much better, being littered with typical one-dimensionalanime archetypes that seem to exist only as backdrop to occasionally poke Yamato or otherwise torment him. 


The only standout character is Honoka Sakurai, who starts off as a typical anime ingenue and love rival for Yamato's affections, only to grow and mature into a young woman who moves past the indecisive and careless Yamato at practically warp speed. Honoka - wherever you are, you dodged a bullet girl. 


Frankly, the best part of this anime is the title song by COACH, "Start Line".  It's great and really deserves a better anime.

Suzuka is the perfect choice for those who want to break from the action-packed for a while and have a little taste of mellow. This series is both Sports and Romance [odd thing is this is classified as shonen, because the manga was published in a shonen weekly] but it's really like a shoujo anime.
The animation and art style  is average but this does not mean that it's unappealing. Actually the characters are cute looking [which kinda reminds me of Gravitation for some reason] Good choice of colors...tho I did have to zap it up a notch with some color saturation.
Both  OP andED are sung in English which was an interesting change of pace for me [which asks the question: is J-POP considered J-POP if sung in English?] but the music was not quite there. I'd almost would like to say I might have liked it if it were sung in Japanese. Because sometimes when you actually hear and understand the words of a song then things like the meaning, significance and sentimentality are received differently. The English Voice actors were top notch, no complaints there.\n
With the story I have to say...there is one GLARINGLY unique characteristic this anime has above most other anime of this genre and that is the fact that this is a love story told from the perspective of a boy.....a HETEROSEXUAL boy! I have to admit I have never come across an anime quite like this. Love stories are traditionally shoujo and thusly told from a girls point of view with a female lead. I've also seen sensitive boys but only in the realm of BL stories. Harem, Ecchi and Hentai are not quite love stories [so I'm not going to accept Love Hina or Mahoromatic] I might accept Boys Be  tho. But this is the first genuine love story I've seen where it's the guy who sits in the main seat of emotional angst. If there are other anime like this, by all means feel free to message me or comment on my page. Overall I liked this story and how it was told. I also liked the drama between the characters as well as the tension.\n
The two main characters seem to be the most developed: Suzuka and Yamato. Also some of the secondary characters like Honoka, are believable. Of course there was a love triangle Suzuka-Yamato-Honoka [I'm not going to say who won] but I was rooting for Honoka. Because Honoka was nice, pretty and a very sympathetic character. That's why she gets the Best Character award for this series. \n\n
**Bishounen Hunter's hottie alert!**\n
Yamato and Yasunobu. Yamato has a very simple look with spiky black hair and large, expressive black/gray eyes. That combined with his simple Asian boy-next-door good looks and his can-do attitude makes him a bishounen hottie. Yasunobu is just a hottie physically, he has the J-POP idol look down pat: the bleached hair, the clothes, the tan. He also has nice eyes. His personality is a bit on the obnoxious side but he is a devoted friend to Yamato.\n\n
This is a lite show that easy to digest. It doesn't get weighted down with cumbersome characters and convoluted plot twists. The story is nicely paced for a “slice of life” anime and I especially love the fact it's a love story told from the viewpoint of a boy.

I love "Slice of Life" anime. Something about characters just going through life, falling in love, going to school. I just get the most enjoyment out of those kind of anime. Suzuka has that feel like no other. The music is amazing, and the layout of Tokyo is beautiful. 
The story is a boy who travels to Tokyo to go to high school there. He lives with his aunt who oparates a womens bath house. While in school Yamato happens upon a girl named Suzuka who he immediately falls for. Only to find out later, she lives right next door to him. the final outcomeis really satisfiying and its a happy one, which I always love in slice of life stories. Suzuka is charming and full of heart, its not something you should go and see right away, but if you get the chance too jump right on it. It's also the perfect anime for a rainy day.

I remember getting home from wal mart with a DBZ Box set, I loved Dragonball Z, considering the only anime I had ever watched was DBZ and Naruto. Now I Know what you're thinkng - "This is supposed to be a review of Suzuka, not Dragonball Z." Well The point of my story is the ad of other Funimation Anime inside that boxset caught my eye. I decided to try one out, and that anime just happened to be Suzuka. This is the Series I remember as my "Gateway Anime". That's why I'm choosing to write my 1st review on it. 
 TheStory: The story was somewhat average, A country boy moving to the city and falling in love. However, That's not of how I thought of it when I watched it, or when I re-watch it. The story was something that had many twists. I could, and still can, relate to the story, as I'm sure most teens would feel the same way. That's Why I'm Giving the Story a 9.


 The Art: The art was Astounding the first time I saw it. Now I know it's not the best artwork ever, but When I look at it today, I still think it's pretty good! However, As  much as I love Anime, I'm not much of a critic on art style. Every Manga Artist is different, that's part of what makes the anime and manga unique. I'm going to give it an 8. 


 The Sound: I remember not being able to get enough of this Anime's Opening song- The song is called "Start Line" and is sung by COACH I believe. The first ending was also Pretty catchy. However, the fact that I had to look these songs up to remember them after all these years brings the overall sound to an 8.5, but I'll put a 9. ;)


 The Characters: Now here was my main selling point on This Anime, The Characters. Now most people will probably tell you that the characters aren't very unique, They're just your average teenagers, with raging hormones, trying to figure out what they're good at, what they want, and basically who they are. I don't tend to disagree, but that's not what makes the characters dull, that's what makes them so amazing. They are so relatable, and I think that's a very important aspect of a good character. I'm going to give Yamato, Suzuka, Honaka, and every other character in this anime a 10. 


 The Enjoyment: I believe you probably understand by now that I enjoyed this Anime a lot. I reccomend it to Anime newcomers and Veterans alike, and giving it a 10 in the entertainment section. What I mainly love about this anime is the twists. I can understand Yamato's actions about 80% of the time, but Dang Girls are unpredictable. lol. (That's not a bad thing for all you ladies out their.) ;)


 Overall: I'm going ton give this a 9/10. Although I can't begin to tell u how close I was to giving this anime a 10/10.  In the end I decided not to let the sentimental value of this anime being my first raise the score that much. I'm going to rate it how it is, A very enjoyable Anime. I hope this review convinces somebody out there to watch Suzuka!

Ok so this is my first ever review, and with the sequel, Fuuka, just dropping I figured now would be as good a time as any to write a review for this show. *Full disclaimer* The main reason I'm writing this is because Suzuka was the first romance anime I ever had the pleasure of watching. I had been into shounen like DBZ and Naruto for years prior, but freshman year of college was a dark time for myself and I found this anime out of the blue, started watching and instantly fell in love with the premise of the romance/slice of life genre. Inshort Suzuka got me through an incredibly trying time in my life and was my gateway to the wonderful anime community as a whole and it will forever hold a special place in my heart because of that! \n\n
With that out of the way, Suzuka is a lovely romance/slice of life anime that throws sports into the mix to make for a very interesting story in my opinion. The use of sports to explore the relationship between two people is nothing new, and there have been many a movie and TV shows that have done it better I can assume, but despite that the story just sticks with ya and I think the MCs' relationship developing around their sporting activities helps with that. While I've seen many a people complain about the contrived nature with which the romance develops in the show, and I can completely understand that point of view, I think that if one looks a little deeper and really tries to get inside the head of the titular character Suzuka, you'll come to have a much more profound understanding of why the romance develops the way it does. Suzuka is great because the feelings presented by the MC Suzuka are so complex, so real that you can feel the conflict that she feels and the way it is presented is quite masterful imo. If you want an anime that will leave you with a huge case of the feels then look no further, and if you are a relative new comer to romance and slice of life and shojo genres, then I think this a perfect gateway anime to get your feet wet, and if you end up wanting to dig a little deeper into it that option is always there as well.

Well, after finishing Suzuka all I can say is that I was utterly disappointed with it. For starters, this anime starts of well. With an almost fairy-tale like quality to it.
Our main character, Yamato, first sees the heroine of the story (Suzuka) on his way over to his new apartment and instantly develops a crush on her. When, by pure coincidence, Suzuka turns out to be his next-door neighbor and lives in the same block of apartments as him.
This is where the fairy-tale aspect comes into the show, there's a lot of charming little coincidences like this and this allows us to really look forwardto how the relationship between the main characters develop.


However, this story wants to be realistic and make the relationship development seem like a struggle. So our two main characters develop strong imperfections out of nowhere. Past episode six, Yamato becomes a thick-headed idiot who can't decide things for himself and follows Suzuka around to an almost stalker-like tendency and Suzuka herself becomes a stubborn, cold-hearted character with more mood swings than any other female character in the anime medium.


This makes the show become a chore to watch and this only worsens when you realize that by episode twenty-four, they still haven't had any heart-felt moments since episode six. (Which is the episode before everything went wrong, surprise, surprise.)


As for the other characters, they're nothing important and mostly bland archetypes. Which doesn't help to pull the story along at all. There's also a second love interest for Yamato, who creates a love-triangle, but she mostly serves as padding and nothing is gained with her on-screen presence.


I've left the art and sound till last because they isn't much to say about them. The art is low-budget but not painful to look at and does get you by if can overlook a few odd bits here and there and the sound isn't too good either. The opening music is good, but the sound in the actual show is boring and repetitive as well as just feeling lackluster.


In the end, I'll wrap up this review that by saying that Suzuka starts off as a sweet, romantic anime with potential. But suddenly tries too hard to be realistic after episode six and in doing so, all the imperfections of the characters grow and become more painfully obvious until they are completely unlikable people. I imagine that Suzuka wanted to be like Pride and Prejudice, but was way out of it's league and ended up forgetting the qualities that made it good in the first place.

I personally enjoyed main character relationships, although all the way trough the story it felt to me that something bad will happen to the main male character and that he would end up in hospital, but the producers actually made it different and in the end it was just a happy ending. Personally I would have like bit more drama, but that's just my taste.

This show is about romance. Nothing more, nothing less. A simple plot but will catch the watcher's interest if romance is his or her cup of tea.
The story is good for many reasons, although sometimes cliché when it comes to the twists. Many different romantic feelings are expressed throughout the series, a lot of it being a display of what the characters are thinking. Several relationships go up and down in terms of intensity, commitment, and questioning whether the relationship is healthy.
I will go ahead and say that I thought the story was perfect regarding pace. Nothing ever goes too rushed or too dragged on.Also, each episode will keep watchers wondering what will happen next, in a very natural way.


The only flaw about the story was the abundant predictability of it. It didn't bother me much though. I think there is some predictability that is necessary in storytelling, especially if it is relating by any means to romance.


I adored mostly every bit of music in the show, setting the correct mood most of the time. In comedic moments, happy/sad moments, etc. I think it was what is expected for a light romance story.


The main character, Yamato, was very interesting to me. He was very determined and joined a sports team mainly for the purpose of winning the heart of Suzuka, who I thought was a likable character as well. This is mainly because of her attitude and clever thinking regarding what Yamato's goal was after all.


I purely enjoyed the series from start to finish. But I give this anime an 8 because it obviously won't appeal to everybody due to some cliché drama and events. Personal enjoyment doesn't determine the score

After finishing a lot of other Romance/Comedy/Slice of life animes, I've been wanting to find yet another one to watch. I was on YouTube just two days ago and Suzuka episode 1 was in my recommendations. I came to this website to read the synopsis and after reading it, I thought I would give it a try.
The anime seemed interesting from the start. I heard from people that this anime wasn't at all what they expected it to be and that it sucked, but I think that they're wrong. This anime was a really good slice of life and can be well related to someof us. People who like romance, drama, humor, and a good slice of life anime should really give this a try.


The anime was somewhat of a slow start but it did have a lot of good character build up within the first couple of episodes. It was something I don't really mind because all animes should have character build up so you know who's who and what not.


After the story really hit off, the anime got more and more interesting and really drew me in. I kept watching episode after episode to find that I finished the whole series in about nine and a half hours or so. I really thought that this anime was great. 


All in all, I thought that the anime was wonderful. It really got to me at some points. It made me tear up but, that's just me. It was a great romance, had really good drama, some good humorous parts, and some really good touching parts that'll give you some goosebumps. Pretty good "Slice of Life" as well.

I still really enjoyed it but I wish I hadn't read the manga first.
I am surprised at some poor reviews and scores since, in my opinion, this is exactly what I expected from a drama/romance and slice of life. The sports thing was a bit tacked on but it was nice to not have a series, for once, where it is so focused on a single subject and you see how their feelings for each other affect their day to day activities. I wish it had a second season so we didn't have to cut off EVERY side story [from the manga] that wasn't directlyrelated to the two mains.








*spoilers* [mostly in the manga tho]

The manga and  anime are almost frame for frame for a very long time. There's some side stories that got pulled which were, admittedly, extraneous to the point of unnecessary but would have been enjoyable. If these had been included we probably would have gotten a second season which would have also covered after Asahina and Yamato got together. I thought that the pregnancy was where Yamato really showed us a lot more about himself as a caring person, and it would have been nice to see the animated wedding.

Art 7/10 - character design was ok. the artist had a way of making the characters have a "good angle" in regards to the characters looking better at certain moments. the animation however was satisfactory. This is probably most noticeable when people are running
As for the story (8/10)... I thought it'd just be the usual in a romance anime -  lead male tries to win over the lead female throughout the entire anime, but I was wrong. The story went into different things such as the lead male actually joining AND making progress in a club. Another thing the story went into, which isthe first time I've seen it in an anime, is a different love interest. This was very interesting and felt like it gave the enjoyment a boost just as the enjoyment might have been peaking. However, this can serve as a distraction to the main plot. I couldn't even support the ending whole-heartedly because of this. Speaking of plot... because the story went into different things it takes until almost the end of the anime before the real route is resumed (like I said.. distraction right?)


Sound 9/10 - Good opening song and the BGM was perfect. The BGM was subtle but it could still emphasize the scenes and make you feel more


Character 8/10 - We've been given a handful of colorful characters here, though not much character development happens. Some of the supporting cast were pretty rounded which was enjoyable. It's silly how important a certain support character is, yet how little impact they made. 


Enjoyment 9/10 - The anime is very interesting. You should give it a try at the very least.
